transcription_data.text: Hey, my friends, it's Matt. This is a 10 minute Bible hour podcast. And when I parent a lot of the times, you know, I sit the kids down and something didn't go right or we're thinking about what we're going to do. We always work on why. I was working on the principles behind it. I like to hear them articulate. Why don't we do that thing? All right, guys, why don't we talk to people that way? Why do we always do the following things? And it's just, you know, it's an opportunity to kind of reinforce the values and all of that stuff and have them kind of internalize it and not just think that it's arbitrary. But also I want them to be grounded in the story deeply and to know that what we believe and what we value as a family and what we're going for, ideally, we won't always get it right. But what we're going for flows out of something much bigger. It's not arbitrary. We didn't just make up a set of values from nowhere. We didn't just go out and see whatever values were popular right now and then think that no, I mean, I mean, we could be wrong and we make mistakes. This is a family, but ideally, if we think it, we're trying to think it because of the values of the kingdom, the values of God, what we see in the Bible and how we're connected to the story of the Bible. Again, I keep saying it, this is an ideal. We're not always going to nail that, but that is the ideal to which we aspire. We're a part of a story. The values all flow out of something bigger. There's a reason that these four letters, the go eat popcorn letters, Galatians, Ephesians, Philippians, Colossians are lumped together. It's because they're very similar in style and tone. I mean, some are a little grouchyer than others, but they're all about the same length. They're all addressing a specific need in the church. They're all written to people who Paul knows. And all four of them have basically the phrase grace and peace to you from God our father and the Lord Jesus Christ. But Galatians is the only one of those that has a comma after the name Christ.
